description:
The players move on the game board through several levels, where they have to answer questions from different themed game cards or follow the instructions on the Event Cards. If a Player answers a question correctly, he continnues till he doesn't know the correct answer to a question or an Event Card ends his move. Movement is determined by a die. The first player to reach the center of the game board, wins the game.

This game was produced as a promotional giveaway for the Vivento Customer Services GmbH, a subsidiary company of Deutsche Telekom AG.

The Rock'em Sock'em Robots Dice Game tries to emulate the fast action of the Rock'em Sock'em Robots of old, with players rolling their dice as quickly as they can to get the same face on all dice — colors or icons, depending on a flip of the match coin. Whoever does this first flips one of the opponent's face-down life markers face up. Two of these markers are blank, and the other three have hits; if all three of your hits are revealed, you lose.

If you've been hit, you can try to roll "block" on all your dice. If you do, flip one of your face-up markers face down again, then shuffle it with your remaining face-down markers.

Dolly's Bookworm is the book lover's game of hide and seek! Like 20 Questions for books, the objective of the game is to find the Bookworm hidden by the Librarian somewhere in a bookshelf of over 30 books.  Players ask Yes or No questions to remove books from the shelves, narrowing the choices until the Bookworm is found. With simple rules, three shelves, four Bookworms, over 65 titles to pick from, and player questions limited only by your imagination, no two games will ever be the same!

Pre-readers can ask questions about the younger titles' colors, locations, and pictures. They can also use the icons to know if there is magic in the game and if the main characters are male, female, or animals.

Older players can test themselves by asking detailed plot and character questions about the older titles. They can also hide multiple bookworms, add a timer, and/or leave the books on the shelf for a serious mental challenge!

Your grandfather started a salt manufacturing business fifty years ago. After thriving for many years, the salt business is now in trouble. Faced by tough competition and a lack of good management, there's a risk of business going bankrupt. It's up to you to take up this challenge and save this family business.

Salt Merchant is a card game of business, luck, math and strategy. Each player becomes a salt merchant and tries to outplay other players and become the first to set up the maximum number of salt manufacturing factories and hence earn maximum money. Your challenges are to acquire good labor and factories, dig more salt water wells, and automate your factories. There's tough competition, too, so you have to be smart, make the right moves, and set-up factories of all different types if you want to regain lost glory.

This card game simulates a dungeon crawl if the entire party was made up of thieves.

Each player is a thief and plays a Chamber card which gives some information about the next room the party is about to enter. This card is played face down and the current player describes its contents, generally by lying. Each player then plays a card face down to express how they intend to deal with the upcoming room, and then everything is revealed.

The players accumulate treasures which equate to victory points and also give each player some special powers depending on the treasure captured.

In Town Center, players build a city – in particular, the town center. They add cubes on their personal board and try to arrange them as best as possible in order to score the most victory points. Each cube represents a different type of module. Flats, shops, offices, generators, lifts, car parks, town hall can be built and stacked during the course of the game. Each module generates influence on adjacent land and on cubes directly below or above.

Each round, players will draft two cubes of various colors, build them on their game board, then eventually stack them in order to make towers according to the building rules. If the players have done their job well, some modules will evolve, becoming bigger in three dimensions. The last phase is an income phase in which players gain money from the shops and parking lots if they are supplied with electricity.

The bigger and higher your city is, the more victory points players will have at the end of the game, which lasts ten rounds – but do not forget to provide electricity to all your flats, shops, and lifts to make them more efficient.


Changes in the fourth edition:

Has a new alternative (two by four) map printed on the reverse of the boards.

Contains the Central Park solo board, previously released separately as the Manhattan t-shirt, on the back of the central board.

Has a bigger box that now fits all the cubes comfortably, and has space for expansions.

Has a bigger rulebook, in separate languages, with updated rules, including rules for up to 8 players to play together by combining two sets of the game.

16 player cubes in 8 colors in each box to allow for games with more than 4 players, by combining 2 copies of Town Center.

Revamped player maps with wider streets that are compatible with future planned expansions.

Added central board with a track around it, a simpler method to track income and points.

Improved player aid that now includes Phase V (in Editions 1–3, Phases IV and V were both encompassed in Phase IV) and more detail in Phase I explanation.

Doubled the size of the cloth bag - now all cubes can all be stored in it without spilling out, and there's space for enough cubes for 5-8 players to be pulled from it.

Note: You need two copies of the same edition* (or a copy of the 3rd edition and a copy of the 4th edition) to play with up to 8 players. Each copy contains enough building cubes and player boards for up to 4 players.

* 3rd and 4th edition are the only 2 editions with the same size of cubes. 1st edition's much smaller cubes, 2nd editions LEGO bricks, and Deluxe edition's way larger cubes are not compatible with the 3rd and 4th edition cubes; the 5–8-player rules require all players to select their cubes from the same draft towers.

Twizmo! is made up of two parts.  A Twizmo cube, which is a twistable puzzle cube with 9 faces per side, and a deck of square cards.  In Twizmo Original, the faces and cards are made up of 6 symbols.  The 54 cards have 9 of each symbol, as does the Twizmo cube.

Twizmo! Original’s simple rules bely the use of spatial and deductive reason along with strategy and a little bit of luck needed for a win.  Its thoughtful pace is great for bringing young and old minds together and its universal appeal transcends language and culture.

Twizmo! is all about creating sets of three matching icons.  Players take turns twisting the cube, with the goal of creating “three-in-a row” groups of similar icons on the top panel.  A “3-in-a-row” set on the cube allows a player to collect all of the visible cards with the matching icon.

When players have collected 3 cards with the same icon, they may turn that set face down; that card set is “closed” and cannot be taken by another player.

To win the game, collect the most card sets, or at any time during the game, collect a set of all nine matching cards for an instant win!

A shaky game dexterity game for 2-4 players from 5 years old.

The turtle is taking a nap on a rock, but five little rascals are having a party on the turtles back. The game contains two very similar variants:
- All five figures start on the turtle and the spinner determines which animal has to be moved. If the turtle tips over you lose a token. Once you lost both tokens you are out of the game.
- All figures start on the table. the spinner determines which animal must be move on/off the turtle but only blue fields may be used. f the turtle tips over you lose a token. Once you lost both tokens you are out of the game.

There are worlds that are ruled by creatures of the sky, great beasts of mythology that have never known anything but dominance.  Generations ago, a rift opened up between these worlds and they became infested with invisible portals that led from one to the other but not necessarily back.  The result was a macrocosm that could not be mapped and in which no one could settle.  Now, thrust together, these great creatures have been locked in an infinite war, for each species believes that it is its world that is the primary and its right to take control of the new Empyrean.

As a player of Titans of Empyrean, you control a squad of 4 titans placed on a tiny hex battlefield in the sky.  Every moving, it is your responsibility to maneuver your titans into positions of opportunity and advantage.  Each unique titan has its own special ability and is armed with a deck of maneuver cards for use throughout the game.  But be careful.  While these powerful maneuvers can be the key to victory, they also double as lifeblood of your titans.  Without them, your titan's wounds cannot be healed.

Position your titans.

Manage your maneuvers.

Attack!

Will your titans control the new Empyrean?

Spurs and Sprockets: Revolutionary Decks is a stand alone game for 2-3 players. It includes 3 new Spurs and Sprockets decks and a new set of rules that will allow players to combine it with the basic Spurs and Sprockets decks to allow for 4, 5 and 6 players to play at the same time. The game decks also include artwork used with the new Flanking rules.

Spurs and Sprockets is a perfect information, abstract strategy game. Players have eight matching tiles that they take turns placing orthogonally into a grid, in an attempt to link three or four in a row. There is no board in Spurs and Sprockets so the grid grows organically, based on the placement of tiles. The grid also varies in size and dimensions based on the number of players.

Spurs and Sprockets sets comes with sixteen tiles and rules for many different ways of playing, ranging from a simple Tic-Tac-Toe-like game where players gain 8 points for four in a row and 3 points for each set of three in a row, to a game where every placement of a tile may result in an attack and removal of another tile.

Survivors are trying to brave the treacherous waters while stranded in the ocean awaiting their helicopter rescue, are you here to save them? NO! You're here to drown them!

Survivors are held up in a structure and players flick dice at the structure hoping to drown as many as possible.

There are 4 rounds and each person drowned is worth a different amount of points. Score the most points by the end of the 4th round and win the game.

Rough Waters Ahead is a print-on-demand dexterity game available on The Game Crafter's website.

In Switch and Signal, you take the role of engineers, signalmen, switchmen, and yardmasters working together to load trains with cargo, navigate a congested railway network, and deliver cargo to the port city of Savannah, Georgia. Switches and signals are used to guide trains along routes. For every train that reaches the port, you gain victory points. You win the game by gaining at least 40 victory points, and 60 victory points is a perfect game.

Compilation in a box of four Spanish classic games from CEFA:

"Misterio"
The game is about solving the mysterious disappearances by a process of elimination. The winner will be the detective that manages to solve the 3 keys: "Mis" "Te" "Rio"

"Alerta Roja"
During the voyage of the merchant ship that transports barrels with radioactive residue, one of them disappears mysteriously.

By satellite, this barrel, is directed by the sea to a far away city.
Ultimatum: In 48 hours the city will be destroyed!!

The most famous secret agent searches , using the most sophisticated equipment he has. Since the barrel, being moved by computers, can transform itself into the same type of vehicle that the agent uses for his search, the search and recovery becomes an almost impossible mission.

"Imperio Cobra"
The game is a standard roll and move fare with the added twist that one of the gamers controls the forces of evil and attempts to stop all of the other players from winning

"Dagon"
In order to win the game you have to search for the “Dagon Symbol” and carry it to one of the cities. This “Symbol” is in the center of the board.

By doing this you will be invested “Kingdom Knight”.
The first one in being invested as a Knight in three different cities will win the game

Objective: be the first reaching space 42
 - moving by turns -

Simple 'Roll & Move' game; choose one of three different routes before you start; there in no space '1' on the board - you must roll at least a '2' getting started. Ending on a red marked space follow instructions glued into the lid.

Note:
Published likely early 1920s.

From the back of the box:

Grab your bag and get ready...You're going on a trip!  How many places will you travel to and how will you get there?  Will you go to the mountains or a tropical island?  Will you visit a museum or an amusement park?  Each time you reach one of your travel destinations, you collect a souvenir to pack in your suitcase.  Whoever packs their suitcase fastest is the winner!

The suspense builds as players draw chance cards and use clever strategy to collect their souvenirs before other players get theirs.  One bad move can change the outcome, so it's a race to the finish to see who will win!

Object of the Game:
Players travel the game board hoping to collect the Souvenirs and Transportation cards they need to fill their suitcases.  The first player to finish packing his or her own suitcase wins the game!

Learn letters with Frida! It’s lunchtime in the rainforest and Frida is collecting letters for her little ones. Spin, find, squeeze, and set four letters in a row first to win this fruity preschool letter game. For 2-4 players.

Teaches letters and the alphabet
Develops fine motor skills
Develops strategic thinking skills
Encourages social skills and turn-taking

Alphabet game for preschoolers

Howdy y’all! It’s a reading race through the southwest! Pick your cards, gallop around the board to round up all your words, and giddy up home before the other players to win! Game features the top 25 building block words.

Teaches 25 key Kindergarten words.

Objective: Be the first reaching space 100
 - moving by turns -

All players have to buy in first. Each player moves forward according die roll. Ending on certain spaces you must pay or collect play money, skip a turn or move again...

Note:
Likely published 1916 +/- one year.

Objective: be the first reaching space 64
 - moving by turns -

Simple 'Roll & Move' game; each player must buy in; ending on a marked space follow instructions glued into the lid:
green - skip one turn; red - earn play money; purple - step 10 spaces forward; blue - step 8 spaces backwards.

Note:
Published likely mid 1930s.

In Fidelitas, players take on the role of faithful citizens in a medieval city who are exerting influence in order to gain the credibility needed to lead the charge against the corrupt crown.

Players play character cards to various locations that make up the city in order to meet conditions of hidden objectives. Each type of character card is associated with a unique action that manipulates cards in the game: the Butcher bullies other characters to new locations, the Student gains more cards, the Soldier keeps the peasants from loitering too long, etc. In this game where keen maneuvering is key, attentiveness to the opposition may uncover hidden motives that seek to foil your bid for power.

The first player to gain a certain number points (depending on the number of players) is determined worthy to lead the revolt and also wins the game.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Brisbane Broncos, an Australian Footballcub; limited edition to raise money for McGuinness McDermott Foundation (now Little Heroes Foundation).

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Carlton (based in Melbourne), an Australian Footballcub; limited edition to raise money for McGuinness McDermott Foundation (now Little Heroes Foundation).

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Collingwood, Victoria, an Australian Footballcub; limited edition to raise money for McGuinness McDermott Foundation (now Little Heroes Foundation).

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from the Soccer World Championship 2014 in Brasilia.

Cartoon Network Fluxx is a card game in which the cards themselves determine the current rules of the game. By playing cards, you change numerous aspects of the game: how to draw cards, how to play cards, and even how to win. At the start of the game, each player holds three cards and on a turn a player draws one card, then plays one card. By playing cards, you can put new rules into play that change numerous aspects of the game: how many cards to draw or play, how many cards you can hold in hand or keep on the table in front of you, and (most importantly) how to win the game.

CN Fluxx features characters from nine different Cartoon Network shows, including Samurai Jack, The Powerpuff Girls, Ed, Edd n Eddy, Gumball, Adventure Time, "Dexter's Laboratory", "Johnny Bravo" and Regular Show.

Klassekampen is a political game modelled on the classical Monopoly game. Each player represents a political party. Votes replace currency, and players strive for control over political issues instead of shares.

The mechanism of the game parallels a traditional Monopoly game. Votes are used to take control over more political issues, which again are used to gain more votes. The aim of the game is to conquer all other players by overtaking all their votes.

The game is published by Klassekampen, a Norwegian radical-left newspaper (the term Klassekampen means 'class struggle'). The game is not sold, but is rewarded to readers who helps the paper in getting more subscribers.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Siegen-Wittgenstein, in Germany.

The harvest is in, and the artisans are hard at work preparing for the upcoming festival. Decorate the palace lake with floating lanterns and compete to become the most honored artisan when the festival begins.

In Lanterns: The Harvest Festival, players have a hand of tiles depicting various color arrangements of floating lanterns, as well as an inventory of individual lantern cards of specific colors. When you place a tile, all players (you and your opponents) receive a lantern card corresponding to the color on the side of the tile facing them. Place carefully to earn cards and other bonuses for yourself, while also looking to deny your opponents. Players gain honor by dedicating sets of lantern cards — three pairs, for example, or all seven colors — and the player with the most honor at the end of the game wins.

The Battle of Macysburg , a Command and Maneuver scenario, portrays a meeting engagement between two well-matched armies converging on a town that’s important as both supply point and road junction. Two players maneuver armies composed of units representing infantry, cavalry, cannon, skirmishers, and leaders, to capture and hold Macysburg, and chase off or destroy the opposing army. The battle lasts for 3 days, 36 day turns divided by 2 night turns.  Units arrive at diverse points on the field during the first 2 days. At night, the armies separate and rally some of the units lost each day.

Command and Maneuver is a simple abstract strategy rules set that allows very rules-light wargames to be constructed.  But as Macysburg demonstrates, it does not necessarily mean a light wargame. By abstracting all of the “fiddly bits” of wargames, what gets represented are the basic ideas of command control, supply, and maneuver to obtain both strategic and tactical advantage over your opponent. Since all combat is deterministic, players aren’t trying to overcome the randomness of combat results tables or dice towers or card draws. But they are trying to overcome chaos created by the combination of the combat and leader rules, which often result in units being out of command.

Armies are fragile in this game, and they “feel” that way. Combat is very bloody and unforgiving. If you are not careful in your dispositions and advances, you can lose a major chunk of your army in a very few turns, without adequate compensation. Players quickly find themselves adopting combined arms tactics and using formations and units in ways that look very much like standard tactics of the era. By doing things very differently than most wargames, the CaM games tease out and examine different aspects of war.

Macysburg, an abstract riff on the Battle of Gettysburg, is just one of the scenarios you can build with the CaM package, available in a Print and Play and in a Vassal version. The terrain (woods, hills, and town squares) is movable, allowing for a different set-up of the game each time. The elements of the scenario are broken down, laid out, and discussed for players to see how the scenario is constructed and how to vary it. Other scenarios are available and more will be provided. Players are encouraged to experiment with the system.

Urosette is an abstract strategy game for 2-5 players with a Moroccan theme. It is similar to both Othello and Go.

Players first take turns placing starter tiles (coins) on the game board. Then, they draw a hand of 3 coins, each having a different ability defined by the arrows on the coin. Placing a coin points to one or more other coins not owned by the player, and that player lays claim to those coins by placing a colored token on them. On subsequent turns, claimed coins change hands.

Once a coin is completely surrounded either by other coins or the edge of the board, it is captured by the last player to successfully claim it. This means a coin captured on your turn could go to an opponent.

The game ends when all of the spaces have been filled with coins, and all of the coins have been captured. Each coin has a number on it, add those up and the player with the highest score is the winner.

Last Starfleet is a strategic co-operative adventure card game that brings out the hero in everyone.

In the year 4010, mankind has ships in space but no colonies beyond Earth. Earth explodes, leaving outbound ships — the last of their kind — to set aside their differences and rally at the nearest life-sustaining planet. Pick up your captains and team in this co-operative strategy card game. You'll work together to battle the elements and safely land your crew to save humanity! Everyone wins in Last Starfleet...or all is lost.

Scotland Rising, which is being released to honor the 700th Year Anniversary of the battle of Bannockburn, is a sharp fight that highlights the tactics of medieval battles on a crowded battlefield: Knights are powerful and hard to bring down; pikemen are best in massed formation; archers have ranged fire but must be protected; and ax men are vicious in a close fight. In the game, players take the command roles of Robert the Bruce and King Edward II to lead their armies toward old-fashioned victory — medieval style — by inflicting damage on their opponent to relieve the siege of Stirling Castle.

Scotland Rising is the first title in Worthington Publishing's "PT-90" game series, a line of wargames that can be played in 90 minutes. The eight-page rulebook has only four pages of rules and four pages of play examples, designer notes, and historical background.

Rink Ratz: The Hockey Card Game provides an authentic hockey experience in card game.

In the game, players play cards onto a common play pile, attempting to create shots and score goals. Play starts at the Rookie level and progresses through the Junior and Pro levels as special cards are added. These special cards introduce other elements of hockey, such as blocked shots, breakaways, power plays and penalty shots to name a few. The team scoring the most goals wins.

monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from the Holiday Property Bond company, located in the U.K..

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Durrell Wildlife Conservation Trust, an international charity organisation.

The Game of Legends is a unique RPG with an important financial part. Gametime is flexible and depends on which one of the possible three endings the players choose. Regain the occupied land from the Dragon, improve your character, fight monsters, attack other players, invest and make good deals. And be the first to be strong enough to attack the Dragon and rule the land! Beautifully drawn characters and awesome graphics provide the base for the unique experience.

From the publishers website:

TARGET FOR TODAY is a solitaire game that recreates American's Daylight Strategic Bombing Campaign against Nazi Occupied Europe during the Second World War. Considerable research, including review of many oral histories gathered from veterans who flew heavy bombers in the Daylight Strategic Bombing Campaign was done to make Target For Today! function as closely as possible to reality. The game was designed to provide YOU, the player, with the ultimate gaming experience depicting the same types of events and decision making processes experienced by our veterans who flew the real-life missions.

Now, YOU are in command of an individual bomber on an individual mission over Hitler's Third Reich -flying either the B-17F or G Model Flying Fortress or the B24D, or J Model Liberator bomber. A series of individual missions are strung together in the campaign game to form the player's tour of duty. Just as it was in real life, the objective of the game for the player is to survive your tour of duty so you can rotate home.

The US Army Air Forces suffered one of the highest casualty rates of any branch of the military services including the US Marine Corps during World War II. The heavy bomber groups of the 8th Air Force flew a combined total of 10,631 strike missions over Europe during the period of this game. The 8th Air Force lost 4145 bombers on these missions. Surviving your tour of duty could be difficult!

TARGET FOR TODAY is an advanced update of Glen Frank's classic game B17, QUEEN OF THE SKIES. Some familiarity with that game is assumed, but "TARGET FOR TODAY" is a completely new game -you do not need to own B-17, QUEEN OF THE SKIES to play it. New tables are included and the rules are organized according to the sequence of play in any typical mission. TARGET FOR TODAY is designed so that each individual mission is fast and easy to play. The campaign game that comprises your tour of duty offers the player a game that is rich in detail, making the game as realistic as possible while still remaining playable.

In the tradition of B-17 Queen of the Skies, and following in the foot steps of B-29 Superfortress, comes a new solitaire game from Steve Dixon. Bob Best and Shawn Rife Steve Dixon. Tentatively titled "Bombs Away!", it has been renamed "Target for Today!". Fly a single mission, a single campaign or fly the entire air campaign from 1942 to 1945 with the 8th or 15th Air Force, piloting either a B-17F, B17G, B24D, B24J and for those so inclined, the YB-40.
 The target list will be greatly expanded for the 8th and 15th Air Forces. Enemy planes we plan to provide are the Me-109, Fw-190, Ju-88, Me-110, Me-210, Me-410, He-162, Me-163, Me-262, and Ta-152.

For more information visit the Consimworld Forum at http://talk.consimworld.com/WebX/.1dd58f17

Battle Board 11" x 17" (mounted) 
Game Counters 176 each .6" 56 each 1.2"
Cards (3"x4") 5 Bomber Types
Rules Book 44 pages
Chart Book 32 pages
Target Book 56 pages
Flight Manual 24 pages
Crew Boards 5 ea. 11" x 17"
Player Aids 10 ea. 8.5" x 11"

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Ströer, a company in Germany.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Hoogvliet, a chain of supermarkets in the Netherlands.

Crisis Averted After listening to the community of BGG we have decided to make the game free to print and play. We have taken the time to ensure the game is a fun experience for all ages and enjoy a healthy debate on your favorite comic book icons. Welcome to Crisis Averted! Players will be dealt cards representing different iconic characters from popular culture, using knowledge of these characters they will avert the crisis set before them. Crisis Averted can be best described as a role-playing multiplayer party card game; where creativity is pivotal to winning. Crisis Averted fuses traditional role-playing storytelling elements with a competitive party game format. The game uses a Judge System, one player per round is the Construct, from their hand of five Crisis Cards they must devise of scenario to the other players.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Diagned, a pharmaceutical distribution division in the Netherlands.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Zappos, a company in the US. Benefit is granted to the Nevada Childhood Cancer Foundation.

The Badger Deck is an expanded deck of playing cards suitable for prototyping new games or for playing a whole range of already available (but possibly out of print) games. With the four standard suits it is an 88-card deck; with 10 suits it is 220 cards.

The basic deck consists of the standard set of suits (hearts, clubs, diamonds and spades) with an additional six suits: pyramids, moons, stars, flowers, coins, bats. All suits have the ranks Ace (A), numbers 0-10, the traditional ranks Jack (J), Queen (Q), King (K) as well as additional ranks Fool (F), Wizard (W), Sorceress (S), Hero (H), Princess (P), Castle (C), Mythical creature/Monster (M).

Can Batman take down The Joker — or will he go mad trying? The action is fast and furious in DC Comics Deck-Building Game: Rivals – Batman vs The Joker as players vie to add the right mix of components to their decks, then launch attacks directly at their archnemesis! This set, which is compatible with any title in the DC Comics Deck-Building Game series, introduces confrontation rules that allow you to attack an opposing character and block cards that ward off confrontations.

The first player to drop the opponent three times wins, although each time an opponent gets dropped, he'll rise up even stronger than before; in game terms, each player has three oversized character cards, and if you're defeated, you reveal the next card with a booosted-up ability. Alternatively, if the main deck runs out of cards, the player with the most VPs wins.

The year is 1947. The war that started a decade  ago has now spread worldwide. The discovery of a crashed alien spacecraft in the Antarctic has led to the development of revolutionary combat walkers that surpass the most advanced tank technology. Old alliances have fragmented and new ones arisen as three major blocs, the Allies, the Axis and the Sino-Soviet Union (SSU) fight the world over for VK, a valuable new resource that power their new fighting machines.

Dust Tactics is a miniatures board game for 2 or more players. The Allied Taskforce Joe starter set contains everything you need to start playing Dust Tactics, including 10 highly-detailed plastic miniatures, unit cards, terrain elements, special Dust dice, and the Dust rulebook. Enter the world of Dust and lead your Allied Taskforce into battle against Axis or SSU Battlegroups.

Note: The rules and cards in this box are based on the version 2 rules, but are slightly different from and not completely compatible with the full Dust Tactics version 2 rulebook.

This game consist of ten different game variants to learn numbers and some basic math. The main components are foam numbers from 0 to 9. There are two pieces of every number and plus, minus and equality signs. Basic idea is to recognize numbers by feeling them in your hand. To prevent you from seeing the numbers, you construct bigger box from the game box and two cardboard walls. Those walls have an hole to put your hand into the box. Hole is covered with cloth.

Basic idea of the games is to find the wanted number(s) from the box. Some examples: 1. You have to pick up numbers in ascending order. 2. You throw 12 sided die and you have to find two numbers that add up to the result. 3. You pick up a tile with a two digit number and find corresponding numbers. And so on. In most advanced games you have to add or subtract numbers or you have to recognize number sequence.

Homeland: The Game is a semi-cooperative game of intrigue, deception and hidden agendas.  Players assume the roles of CIA analysts, directing agency resources to combat the rising tide of global terrorism. Be warned, not everyone is what they seem.


    Stay Alert: New threats are constant.  Every card played matters.  Any action could be the difference between stability and catastrophe.



    Be Vigilant: Use every tool at your disposal to stop impending terrorist threats.  Deploy soldiers, insert agents and recruit key assets to neutralize imminent dangers and keep the nation safe.



    Trust No One:  Not everyone is what they seem.  Watch your rival's actions carefully to try to decipher if they are working against you!  


Homeland: The Game draws 3 to 6 players into its web of espionage and paranoia. As the pressure mounts, will your actions tip the balance towards national security or global chaos?

A game about the battle of Boreml (April 19th, 1831) which was biggest cavalry battle during the Russo-Polish War (November Uprising).

Game was published in 33 issue of "Taktyka i strategia" magazine. It uses "Napoleon" system rules.
